header.topics: Justice system, work, climate, money, transport, travel, family, education
header.activity: Acquaintances having a chat after work.

body.u: okay so what is it that you do here in the magistrate court?
okay I am a part-time court usher which basically means er I work twenty hours a week um Monday Wednesday and Thursday
and the role of an usher is really about keeping the court moving
so I try and establish what cases are in during the course of the day and liaise with the legal adviser
and also the er CPS lawyer
and just see that our lists er all match and then I make sure that everybody's paperwork is the same and then I try and find out if any of the offenders are here
and if they are are they represented by a solicitor er er whether they want to see the duty solicitor which is a free service
that they can have and er you know if it's a youth have they got a parent with them? Er are they known to the youth offending team? That sort of thing
and basically it's just about keeping the court moving
it sounds like a lot of responsibilities
not really it's er I suppose it yes it sounds that way but er it is really about knowing your way round the court
and er just as I said making sure that er everybody's in the right place at the right time
er and maybe just you know sort of trying to make sure that the paperwork is perhaps collected from wherever
just so that er it keeps going rather than end up having stop start situations
Cos that saves saves er everyone time and
well I think it's the magistrates more than anybody else
Cos they er well they're volunteers
and they want to try and keep it fluid
and er so really that's what it's all about
um but it's I mean it's quite interesting
meet all sorts of different people today we've had um tut er a group of four who er had committed a burglary and one had er driven very dangerously and er they got lots of supporters here like
parents and girlfriends and and er er fellow er offenders and they were very vocal
so er but yeah that's what makes it quite interesting really
er but er did you feel at risk or threatened?
tut no because you're in a quite social environment anyway
and I think as long as you try and just speak to people I think you know if you try and explain
that really it's not gonna help if they start er being vocal
and making contact with people in custody that sort of thing so that's
were they were they being vocal in a
yes because they're not getting their own way
so I think that's really what it's all about
so yeah so basically that's er roughly er it
and it and I mean it can be quite physical really as y
as you your mum'll probably tell you er cos you're sort of up and down stairs with um sort of paperwork and mak
er making sure again that sort of things like warrants or er um files are
with the right sort of people so it saves you having a workout
because you're up and down the stairs every time
there you go and you save money on the gym
that's right so that's quite nice really so so yeah so there you go so yeah
and you said that some the magistrates are volunteers?
er d does that always happen at a local
yeah in ma in magistrates court
they're all volunteers er they go through an interview process er I think that's quite rigid actually um and they er then have to do so many hours
and er er they some of them are trained to deal with youth matters or family matters
and er then er er I suppose they have a little bit of training in the law so that they've got some basic skills
but the idea is that er the legal adviser who sits sort of below the magistrates
er they're trained legally they're solicitors basically
so the magistrates'll go out and make a decision er and then they'll call for the legal adviser to go in and she or he will just give them advice to say yes that's within the law or
er and then just yeah sort of give them some advice
and er really the legal adviser's the person that runs the court
yeah sh he or she obviously has the knowledge and
and advises them but you know fair play to them they come in and
how how often do they usually come in?
well I'm not sure how many hours they have to do
but I s I know certainly they have to do so so many because I know because we haven't got much work at the moment they're
really sort of anxious that they get their hours in
er that's what they do so
as I say fair play to them
and they and they come from all s sort of backgrounds
definitely well my old chemistry teacher is a magistrate here
well I think that's good then
because you know you've got an idea of the issues in schools
er and I think n perhaps a background in social care
that sort of thing or I w as I say teaching or maybe health
er because some of the issues that some of these folks have
er and the reasons why they're here
perhaps involved with drugs or they've got family issues that sort of thing
so it's I I think it's good to have er a bit of an understanding
of er about why they're here and what's open to them
and they can advise them you know obviously they use probation a lot as well
um who if if the magistrates feel they need to know a little bit more about that person
to see whether they're suitable for er probation er report
having some guidance maybe on drugs or um any other abuse
er or if it's er an assault you know maybe they need to look at their anger management that sort of thing

um they will then er give them that er guidance and the magistrates will then look at them and say yes okay this person could do that if they've got sort of medical needs then er they're perhaps not suitable for doing work
er or like I had a guy today who'd got a drink issue and er they said he wasn't suitable for doing work
Cos I suppose if he comes along and he's had a few few jars
oh is that like community service
so he if he was I don't know perhaps working in a shop or er you know he's er in close contact with a number of other people
then it's not fair is it if he's
so all the people like that usually get fined? Or?
they sometimes they get fined er in this case his case was er what had happened to him? I think he was given a suspended sentence
because he'd got something else as well
decided that a suspended sentence whether that will stop him from reoffending
I really don't know but there we are
so how are you enjoying being back in the UK after all your time in Spain?
well um tut enjoying I've been enjoying the weather recently
not so much right now but Um yeah I wouldn't saying enjoy
is the right word for it but
would you rather be in Spain would you?
life was more enjoyable in Spain
things are yeah things are a bit more serious
er you can you can bank on them a bit you can bank on things a little more in England which you need to do life can't just all be fun fun fun can it you know
that's true and I suppose in the sunshine it's quite nice to just have that approach and er er
I think things are a little bit sort of lighter aren't they and
you can enjoy having a sort of um tut a meal outside or a drink outside that sort of thing whereas here it's oh it's not that sort of available is it
and er people I think er feel much happier in themselves if they er um if they're in the sunshine don't they
I think er yeah your woes are a lot easily more easily forgotten
if you can just go outside and it's a beautiful day and
you just forget everything and every I mean I noticed it when Eng um in England when it's been beautiful weather unexpectedly
um just as a pedestrian walking on the pavement people stop when you're crossing the road
people stop in their cars and they wave you across and they're smiling
is that the effect of sunshine? That's quite nice
people say hello to each other
when they walk into shops when it's sunny
and everyone's a lot more relaxed
much happier yeah they are it's true it's true So yeah so I can understand why yeah but er
maybe in the future you'll go back do you think?
unless unless I win the lottery
tut ah what about that that what's that that guy in er in America was it? Five hundred million he won
five hundre that's just obscene isn't it
huh that's just too much money I mean
twenty-six million a year he was going to have
I think I think I'd prefer

or some of our debt with all that sort of m

if they win there'll only be

sort of you know small amounts

over over a period of months
until they actually come back into the country like one guy went to New Zealand
and he paid up before he went and I think his winnings paid for the time he was in New Zealand
so that was quite nice wasn't it really so
maybe I should start maybe I should start
you never know you never know
absolutely yeah so there you go

so and how's the driving lessons going?
oh not too bad it's strange though I feel like I'm in a kind of tut bubble when I'm driving
it's like like a parallel reality and it's not really me in char in control of the car I f like the car's moving and it's doing what I'm saying but I don't know it's really weird
oh really? And er so what's made you now decide do you think?
oh that's good isn't it and er how many lessons have you had?
yeah so is it going okay?
it's going okay yeah the the I've got a fantastic driving le er instructor
um but he's really he's got a good sense of humour and
he's all the time feeding me instructions
and manages to carry on quite er a very civilized chat at the same time
so tut he really I think he d that's probably his technique
he tries to get people thinking and talking about other things
that's good and er and have you just driven locally then I guess?
I was up the last week in fourth gear
which I thought was quite scary at first but then I thought
I can do this good for you so
but I'm just because he is feeding me all the instructions all the time I don't know what would happen
how I'd react in a situation that
er so predictable I don't know
and are you er driving with anybody else in between lessons? Or are you?
my dad's not that great a teacher
he tends to be um you know he's he's he tries to be but then he ends up giving instructions that have got nothing to do with the task in hand and
I see and your mum? Would your mum?
but I don't think she's up for it
no no? Maybe good cos you might just fall out couldn't you yeah

but er you know if you think like she obviously likes her clothes she's only young likes her clothes likes going to concerts and things really she'll have the added responsibility of A paying three thousand three hundred
